Award.AwardTitle: Measuring Complex STEM Thinking Using Epistemic Network Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the researchers propose to investigate an alternative model for assessing complex thinking in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education. The method, Epistemic Network Analysis, is said to measure student skills, knowledge, identities, values, and epistemology.

Two iterative design cycles over five years are proposed. The investigators will use existing data to do psychometric analyses, develop visualizations, develop a toolkit, and work with and disseminate a toolkit to a community of early adopters. The work will be conducted using data from several engineering education games. Dissemination will be in the form of the toolkit and academic publications.

This work is important because it represents a departure from current thought about assessment and the notion of isolating content learning from values, epistemologies, and skills. Because the work proposed by the investigator retains such data and examines their interdependencies, the ENA method represents a potentially transformative approach to assessing complex STEM thinking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Assessing Complex, Collaborative STEM Thinking

We live in an age of big data, and the question of how to deal with big data is critical to the study of learning. On one hand, the advent of online courses, intelligent tutoring systems, educational games and simulations, computer-based tests, and other educational technologies mean that the data available on learning processes and outcomes is growing exponentially. On the other hand, the technological advances that create big data also give us the tools to analyze it. The tools of data science make it possible to analyze larger and larger volumes of data.

In this project, the Epistemic Analytics lab at the University of Wisconsin–Madison developed tools that address the challenges associated with analyzing massive amounts of data in order to understand complex phenomena such as learning and collaboration. While this project focused on the development of statistical techniques and user-friendly systems for implementing them, it became apparent that researchers needed not only new techniques for analyzing big data but entirely new approaches to thinking about big data. Thus, this project also developed an entirely new method for modeling learning and other complex phenomena: quantitative ethnography.

Quantitative ethnography is about understanding why, in the digital age, the old distinctions between qualitative and quantitative research methods, between the sciences and humanities, and between measurement and understanding, limit the kinds of questions we can ask, in some cases, and lead us to accept superficial answers in others. Specifically, quantitative ethnography addresses two of the most significant challenges in the analysis of learning.

First, it provides the theoretical and practical measurement machinery to combine statistical inference with the interpretive power of qualitative, grounded, and humanistic data analysis in contexts where massive amounts of rich data are available. Classical statistical techniques were not designed to handle massive quantities of data, and no human could read, let alone analyze qualitatively, even a fraction of most educational datasets. Quantitative ethnography makes it possible to construct qualitative assessments of learning at scale. Importantly, the method addresses the short-comings of traditional qualitative and quantitative approaches, neither of which scale well: the former risks finding phenomena that are not representative of broader patterns, while the latter risks finding arbitrary patterns that are bound to exist in any large collection of data.

A second critical problem in assessing learning is the measurement of complex and collaborative thinking. When students work in groups to solve problems, researchers can assess either the work of the group or the work of a specific member of that group. In collaborative problem solving, however, it is impossible to understand the work of an individual without accounting for the contributions of the other members of the group.

Epistemic network analysis (ENA), a statistical technique for measuring and visualizing complex, collaborative STEM thinking that was developed in this project, addresses this challenge by modeling student learning in terms of the connections individual students make—in their speech or actions—among key skills, knowledge, values, and decisions. These connections can be between things that the student does independently, or between things that a student does and things that other members of the group say and do. ENA models learning as a network of connections, where each student’s network includes the relevant connections that he or she made in the context of the activities of the team. This makes it possible to assess collaborative problem solving without specifying explicitly a correct sequence of problem solving steps, and without creating a simulated team where the responses of a student’s simulated teammates are carefully controlled.

Quantitative ethnography, and associated statistical techniques such as ENA, have been used to analyze and understand diverse phenomena, from patterns of brain activity in fMRI data to coordination of gaze behaviors during collaborative work. These tools are currently being used by upwards of 250 researchers at more than 50 institutions in 16 countries. Researchers are using quantitative ethnography and ENA to address critical questions in a wide range of fields, including computer science, cognitive neuroscience, medicine and surgery, engineering, mathematics, law, public health, ethics, history of science, and learning science.

To learn more about quantitative ethnography, ENA, and other analytic tools developed by the Epistemic Analytics lab, visit http://epistemicanalytics.org/, or watch “Tools for Quantitative Ethnography” at http://isls-naples.psy.lmu.de/intro/all-webinars/shaffer_video/index.html.
